body:
Thanks for your report!

I've bisected this down to 6c5fab0668c1872fe827507f45ef400a20e8c646 which was introduced in #45734.

It looks like intended behavior, but it's unclear to me why exactly this was changed. /cc @fatkodima

Yes, that was intentional. See related issue https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/45668 for the discussion of the problem.

cc @byroot

Thanks for the response. I'm still a bit unclear on the rationale behind this change; looking at the reported behaviour in #45668 , it seems to me that we have the same behaviour with other types, not just enums, so not sure where the difference is. 
Eg if the column is a simple integer and we define `attribute :wrong_attributee` on Post model, we still will not throw on `new_post = Post.create!(wrong_attributee:  2) # column is not in the schema cache, so why no error?` and the Post will not be created with wrong_attributee = 2, just like in the code reported re: enum. (Happy to post a full test example if useful)

Either way though, I guess it boils down to the statement 

> While it is possible to have attributes without the columns (defined with the [attribute](https://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/Attributes/ClassMethods.html#method-i-attribute) method), the enum (which is also defined by attribute) should always have a corresponding column.

Perhaps we just need some documentation/explanation of this?

I also have a project that is being significantly impacted by this. Is there a "simple/straightforward" way to fix the offending enum definitions in the models? Currently, this is preventing me from upgrading to Rails 7.1.

> Is there a "simple/straightforward" way to fix the offending enum definitions in the models?

It's not quite clear to me what you are asking. Invalid enums raise an error on boot, you should be able to catch them by running your test suite.

Or are you asking for something else?

In several of my project's models, we define `enum`'s whose values are used to populate a `character varying` column (we are using Postgres). An example `enum` is below:
```ruby
    enum order_by_types: {
      email: 'email',
      fax: 'fax',
      phone: 'phone',
      website: 'website'
    }
```
Before Rails 7.1, referencing and using `enum`'s like `order_by_types` above did not raise any errors. With Rails 7.1, tests are now failing with errors like the following:
```
     RuntimeError:
       Unknown enum attribute 'order_by_types' for Deals::Judgment
```
What I am looking for is some guidance on how best to fix this. It appears that we can no longer define `enum`'s inside models without a corresponding database table column.

I don't follow. You say:

> we define enum's whose values are used to populate a `character varying` column

And then:

> we can no longer define enum's inside models without a corresponding database table column.

So first you say the enum is backed by a column, then you say it's not. It's really confusing.

My apologies...it looks like it may be a simple case of `order_by_types` not matching the `order_by_type` column name. I am going to check my `enum`'s and correct the name mismatches to see if that fixes things.

> it looks like it may be a simple case of `order_by_types` not matching the `order_by_type` column name

If that's so, then that's exactly why we made this change. To catch these typos.
Changing the `enum` name to match the corresponding column name is fixing things for me. Again...my apologies for the confusion/noise in this thread.

I think as jkwuc says, that wasn't actually related to my original question.

It seems like the my issue (enums for attributes which are not backed by a column) is now explicitly unsupported, and the way forwards is to rewrite the enums into arrays and explicitly validate inclusion in those values, and manually feed in the enum options and i18ns to the inputs on forms, etc. If anyone has elegant ways of doing this then would be interested to hear!

I guess the documentation for enum does say pretty clearly that it should be backed by a DB column, so hopefully that's sufficient for others going forwards to know that this use case isn't supported.
> Declare an enum attribute where the values map to integers in the database, but can be queried by name

> my issue (enums for attributes which are not backed by a column) is now explicitly unsupported

If you have time, I'd be curious to hear what was your use case and how it worked. It's unlikely we'll revert this change (even more so now that @jkwuc89's comments showed it caught some real world issues), but perhaps there's some other change of feature for your use case.

issue.title: Support non-column-backed attributes for `enum`
issue.body:
Follow-up to #45734.

This re-adds support for using `enum` with non-column-backed attributes while still guarding against typos in enum attribute names.  When using `enum` with a non-column-backed attribute, the attribute must be previously declared with an explicit type.  For example:

  ```ruby
  class Post < ActiveRecord::Base
    attribute :topic, :string
    enum topic: %i[science tech engineering math]
  end
  ```

Fixes #49717.

body:
Eventually I would like to port `ActiveRecord::Enum` to Active Model, so I think it would be nice to support non-column-backed attributes.  Otherwise, there would be a disparity between `enum` in an Active Record model and `enum` in an Active Model model.

Instead of checking for a database column, we could check that the attribute has a declared type.  In other words, it must either be defined in the schema or be declared with an explicit type via `ActiveRecord::Base.attribute`.

I've submitted #49769 to accomplish this.

@jonathanhefner I was working on a PR to port ActiveRecord::Enum to ActiveModel some time ago.
I'll see if I can get that ready.
Looks like a great solution, thanks for the PR @jonathanhefner and for the continued support @byroot
